ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ELECTED PRESIDENT
(Protection of reserves)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Prime Minister whether he will give details of the list of problems with the Government

Column: 1821

encountered by the first Elected President during his term of office.

    2. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Prime Minister whether the Net Investment Income or income derived from past reserves is defined as earnings for past reserves or current reserves and whether there has been a change of definition since the Elected President's office was created.

    3. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Prime Minister whether all assets belonging to the state have been accurately identified, accounted for and recorded and whether a list of assets can be made available to Parliament.

    4. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Prime Minister if he will direct all Ministries and key Statutory Boards to not only maintain a complete listing of Physical Assets, which are defined as Reserves, but also ensure that these land parcels and buildings are properly maintained so as to preserve and protect their value.

    5. Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad asked the Prime Minister whether it will be possible for the Government to disclose annually, after the close of the fiscal year, (i) the amount of reserves, if any, accumulated during the year by the current Government; (ii) the portion transferred to the official reserves (guarded by the President); and (iii) the remaining amount of cumulative funds useable to fund deficits, wherever applicable.

    6. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Prime Minister if he will respond to the President's comment that he suspects some Ministers may find him a nuisance and that public officers should change their mindsets and see it as their constitutional duty to help the Elected President protect the past reserves.

    7. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Prime Minister, with regard to Net Investment Income (income earned from past reserves), if he will disclose (i) its magnitude in 1997 and 1998; (ii) the

Column: 1822

rationale for the recent change in its treatment from being considered as part of past reserves to being considered as part of current reserves; (iii) whether such a change is temporary or permanent; and (iv) why it is still an unresolved issue.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, Questions 1 to 7 are all related to remarks made by the President at his press conference on 16th July 1999. The Government will make a Ministerial Statement addressing fully the issues raised by the President. It had planned to do so today, but in view of the demise of Mrs Ong Teng Cheong, it has postponed the Statement to a sitting of Parliament scheduled for later this month.

    I therefore request the Speaker's permission to defer answering these questions until after the Ministerial Statement has been made, so that the issues can be seen in their proper context.

    Mr Speaker: You have my permission.

CLOB ISSUE

(Status)



    8. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Deputy Prime Minister if he will give an update on the status of the Clob issue, and what are the possible solutions being considered to resolve the matter.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I last updated Parliament on the Clob issue in May 1999. Since then, Mr Akbar Khan's cash offer has closed with 359 investors out of more than 172,000 accepting. Three more private sector offers have been announced, but none have obtained regulatory approvals and been formally made. Akbar Khan's Straits Fund Sdn Bhd is offering units in a closed-end investment fund in exchange for Clob investors' securities. It is not yet known at what price the Clob securities will be valued or how Clob investors are to trade these units. Tungku Abdullah's Bintang Melewar Sdn Bhd is offering Clob investors three options, including units in a closed-end investment fund, fund management services for

Column: 1823

larger investors, and custodial services for non-accepting investors. And the third private sector offer is for Clob investors to swap their securities for an equal proportion of shares in Telekom Malaysia and United Engineers of Malaysia ("UEM"). The two companies have said that they will purchase the Clob securities at a discount to market prices, and sell shares in Telekom Malaysia and UEM at a premium to market prices.

    Any offeror intending to offer Clob investors shares or units in investment funds for their Clob Malaysian securities will need to issue a full prospectus in Singapore. This prospectus must be approved and registered with the Registry of Companies and Businesses ("RCB"). The RCB verifies that the prospectuses comply with the disclosure requirements set out in Singapore's Companies Act, and will register the documents if it is in the public interest to do so. In evaluating the public interest, the Registrar will take into account all relevant factors and considerations. The Securities Investors' Association of Singapore ("SIAS") has urged the Registrar not to register prospectuses of offers until a comprehensive solution is in place for all Clob investors. The Registrar has stated that it will take into account the views of the SIAS, which is the only body representing investors, together with other information and views that it may receive regarding the offers.

    The Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) has stated that it will not stand in the way of private sector offers. However, there should be clear and reasonable arrangements for non-accepting investors to trade their shares on the KLSE. When the offers are formally made, investors should study the terms of each offer carefully before making a decision. The agreement between CDP and SCANS contains arrangements for Clob investors to transfer their securities to individual account with the Malaysian Central Depository, and thereafter trade these securities on the KLSE. SCANS continues to be in breach of this agreement, but investors should not feel pressured into accepting any offers if they are not satisfied with the offerors' terms.

Column: 1824



    The SES is continuing to explore all means of resolving the problem. It has been taking advice from lawyers on the legal position. The SIAS has also announced that it too is consulting lawyers, as the legal position of the Clob investors is different from that of the SES.

    Meanwhile the SES has submitted a proposal of its own to the KLSE, suggesting a staggered release of the Clob securities over 12 months, without prejudice to its rights under the CDP-SCANS Agreement. The proposed mechanism will result in a daily release of Clob securities with the value of a mere 0.015% of KLSE's total market capitalisation. This effect on KLSE stock prices should be negligible. This is a fair solution which directly addresses Malaysian concerns that any solution to the Clob issue must not disrupt the KL market, and enables Clob investors to exercise their rights under Malaysian law to trade their securities. The two exchanges are currently in communication on the proposal. And the SES will inform Clob investors as and when progress is made.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he has any expectation on the timeframe by which this issue could be resolved since the CDP-SCANS Agreement would have to do the transfer by the end of the year. And if it is not done by the end of the year, would it lead to some legal process being introduced to enable the Clob investors to get their shares transfered?

    The second question is whether the SES will assist in special cases where there are rights issues or warrants which have a timeframe expiry, for example, rights issues may be called within a certain timeframe or warrants may expire within this year, and whether the SES can approach the KLSE for special considerations to allow the Singapore owners to either exercise their conversion rights for such issues.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, on the timeframe, it is not the case that the end-of-the-year is the deadline, because

Column: 1825

the agreement was settled last year (signed in September 1998) and was meant to be implemented as soon as possible. There is no specific timeframe. The end-of-the-year is not a deadline for the agreement between CDP and SCANS. There have been some statements by one of the offerors, I believe, that at the end of the year, if this matter is not settled, the shares may be confiscated. But the SES is taking advice on that, and its advice so far is that even if the shares are transferred to the Minister of Finance in Malaysia, the titles still belong to the shareholders and they still have a claim on those shares. So they are not expropriated. But we are clarifying this position because it is an important point on which I am sure Clob shareholders would want reassurance.

    As for the legal process, as I said in my statement, SES is taking legal advice and the shareholders' association is also taking legal advice. I do not think we should rule anything out but neither are we seeing that as the only solution.

    As to when the whole package can be solved, as Members have been reading in the newspapers recently, the Malaysians are gearing up for elections and I think their minds are likely to be on other weightier matters for the time being. So it will be some time before the matter would be solved.

    On special cases like rights issues and warrants, I have to ask the Stock Exchange to look into the matter but we will have to study the specific cases.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister said that to make Clob legal, the Malaysian authorities would have to go to Parliament, in other words, to pass a resolution to make Clob illegal.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Clob is not illegal. Even today, it is not illegal. Clob is an offshore market. It operates outside Malaysia, just like people trade in Malaysian shares in London or Hong Kong. It does not require Malaysian law to make it legal. It did require the cooperation of the KL Stock Exchange

Column: 1826

because Clob had to operate nominee accounts and also investors had to buy additional shares, rights issues, and so forth. Indeed, it complied with all the rules and regulations of the KL Stock Exchange all the many years it was in existence. In September last year, the KL Stock Exchange changed its rules and Clob reassessed its position and decided that it was no longer viable for it to operate under the new rules. But there is no question of Clob being illegal.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, in view of the difficulty of the Clob issue so far and the so-called unsatisfactory result in the level of negotiation between the Singapore Stock Exchange and the Malaysia Stock Exchange, does the Government intend to take up the issue with the Prime Minister of Malaysia?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, the Government had already done so. If you read my previous statement in May 1999, I explained that after the matter reached an impasse at the working level, the two Prime Ministers discussed it in Hanoi when they met during the ASEAN Summit. After the meeting, Dr Mahathir came out and told the press that Clob would be part of the package of issues to be negotiated between the two governments, including water, railway land, CPF, and so on, and he mentioned specifically Clob. But, unfortunately, the Malaysian Government subsequently changed its position.

    On 17th May this year, Prime Minister Mahathir made a different statement and he said, "No. Clob is not one of the issues. Clob is a separate matter." But the Singapore Government has said, in our negotiations with the Malaysians, that while this is something we can negotiate separately, by the time the main negotiations are settled, Clob should not remain outstanding. So the two can proceed on parallel paths but they must reach a conclusion at the same time. But both packages may take some time to resolve because, in the nature of our relations with Malaysia, these are not easy problems. So we will have to wait and see what happens.

Column: 1827



    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Deputy Prime Minister say that he would not expect any form of solution until after the Malaysian general elections?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: I did not quite say that. I said that they have their minds on other matters right now. I am sure you understand the psychology. So I think it is more likely it will be settled after, rather than before, the general elections.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SUZHOU PROJECT


    9. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether the Government is still hopeful of recovering all monies invested in the Suzhou project.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Jeyaretnam last asked about investment of public monies in Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) in January 1998. In my reply, I explained the composition of SSTD, that is, the Singapore consortium participating in the SIP project. I also provided the amounts its shareholders had invested. I pointed out that as the shareholders include publicly listed companies and MNCs, the SIP project had to be viable. Any losses sustained would have to be made public and available for scrutiny by the international investment community.

    I also explained the problems faced by the SIP as a result of aggressive promotion by the Suzhou Government of a rival industrial park next door, the Suzhou New District (SND).

Column: 1828



    Since January 1998, both sides have carried out extensive consultations to resolve the problems. They thoroughly evaluated the progress of the SIP and the experience gained so far, and sought to work out jointly the best way to advance the project, given the circumstances. The discussions were successful, and resulted in a memorandum of understanding (MOU) signed by the two sides in Singapore on 28th June 1999, and published.

    Initially the Singapore side suggested that SND, that is, the rival, suspended its marketing for five years, so that full attention could be given to accelerate SIP's development. The Chinese side explained why they could not suspend SND, but expressed their commitment to SIP's priority status by offering to coordinate the marketing of the two parks. The Singapore side accepted the Chinese explanation of their constraints. Hence, the need for a fundamental review.

    The MOU is a comprehensive package redefining the objectives and structure of the project, and resolving many long outstanding problems. Its main points include:

    a) Refocusing the SIP project on completing the first 8 sq km by 1st January 2001.

    b) Transferring majority ownership and management control of CSSD, the joint venture company from Singapore to China on 1st January 2001.

    c) The Suzhou Government and the joint venture company to continue to look after the interests of SIP tenants and investors. They guarantee that the changes to the project will not affect their commitments to these tenants and investors.

    d) The Suzhou Government will respect SIP's priority status by recommending all suitable projects to the SIP, encouraging investors to choose SIP, and taking concrete measures to pre-empt disorderly competition between SIP and SND.

Column: 1829



    e) The Suzhou Government will encourage population from Suzhou old city to move to SIP so as to accelerate SIP's development and growth.

    f) Both sides will accelerate the adaptation of Singapore's experience. Beyond 1st January 2001, software transfer will continue through attachments and training of Chinese officials in Singapore.

    g) Both sides have also settled all the outstanding commercial issues, to enable the project to go forward with a clean slate and the best chance of success.

    h) Both sides will jointly assist CSSD to enhance its financial performance and to enable CSSD's early listing.

    These measures will put the SIP project on a workable track and improve the joint venture company's financial viability. The Chinese side have assured us that they will do their utmost over the next 18 months to implement the agreements and make the 8 sq km area a success. The Singapore side remains committed to the project and will do all it can to achieve a positive outcome.

    The shareholders in the Singapore consortium have fully endorsed the MOU. They include American, Japanese, Dutch and Korean corporations. The consortium has slightly increased its investments in the joint venture companies since January last year. I have circulated an updated list of investments (Cols. 1867-1870) by consortium members and other Government-linked companies in the SIP project. Members should have it on their seats. The total amount invested by statutory boards and GLCs in the project so far is US$147 million. In addition, as part of the package deal in the MOU, Temasek has agreed to guarantee a loan of up to US$65 million to the project, for a fixed period up to 31st December 2003, in return for a commercial fee from the members of the Singapore consortium. Beyond these commitments, the

Column: 1830

Singapore consortium does not expect to inject further amounts into the SIP project.
LIST - SSTD SHAREHOLDERS (Cols. 1867-1870)


    The strategic objective of the SIP project was not just to earn a profit for the joint venture, but to be a vehicle for software transfer. But shareholders in the Singapore consortium decided to invest in CSSD based strictly on commercial considerations. They have always emphasised that the project must be commercially viable. Unless it can earn a reasonable return, the consortium cannot justify its investment, and SIP cannot support the software transfer.

    The shareholders in the Singapore consortium evaluated the viability of the project critically before committing themselves. But like any other project, it was subject to normal commercial risks. There could not be any certainty of profit.

    For a combination of reasons, it has proved more difficult for SIP to become profitable than the Singapore consortium initially expected. However, with the package of solutions now agreed upon by both parties, and the assurances given by the Chinese, the SIP project has a reasonable opportunity to turn around and become profitable in the medium term, provided the external investment climate does not deteriorate.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask the Deputy Prime Minister why has the Memorandum of Understanding not been made public? I understand from the librarian that it was not presented to Parliament. May we know why?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Memorandum of Understanding is a commercial document which was published when it was signed, and it was all over the newspapers.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether it is true that the Suzhou project costs the Government more than $30 billion of public funds, and this was

Column: 1831

apparently alleged by Dr Chee Soon Juan in a speech he made at Raffles Place in December last year.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no truth at all. I had already given Parliament a full update on the status of SIP in January 1998, giving figures similar to what I have just stated again, which is $147 million. Dr Chee Soon Juan made a speech last year at Raffles Place where he said that if we continued talking about Suzhou, we were bailing out $30 billion of public funds, not "his" money ("his" meaning Mr Lee Kuan Yew) but $30 billion of taxpayers' money. I do not know where he got his figure from, but Members will know that this is Dr Chee Soon Juan's statement and, with him, accuracy and facts are matters of taste rather than morals.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether it is reassuring to hear from the Deputy Prime Minister that the Government hopes that it will show returns. What I want to know from the Deputy Prime Minister is: is this a pious hope or are there any realistic expectations and, if so, when do we expect any returns?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, these are commercial propositions. There is a commercial consortium. They have spent 19 months negotiating the MOU, which they have signed. It is still not guaranteed that the project will become profitable. But they have to make the best of the project in the circumstances, and we will have to see in due course what happens. I think it is too early to speculate.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I do not know whether the Government has sufficiently considered the Suzhou New District before committing its investment which has resulted in today's position. I understand that the Suzhou New District had been in existence before the Government decided to make an investment. Was it prudent for the Government to make the investment and pulling in the commercial establishments which are now suffering losses and facing an uncertain future?

Column: 1832



    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Sir, in retrospect, obviously, we did not pay enough attention to it. But there was a reason. We were aware of it but there was a reason why we started on a different area, and that is because we were not just building an industrial estate, but building a township complete with schools, houses, infrastructure, industrial park, utilities, everything. Therefore the idea was to look for a fresh piece of ground and start in order to have a clean slate. We believed that the Suzhou authorities would give clear priority to the SIP project over SND and indeed this was so for the first few years of the project. But as time went on, the competition and rivalry became a problem and finally came to a head.

    As Members know, I think in November 1997, one of the Vice Mayors of Suzhou went to Germany to promote SND, the rival, and told the German investors that they should come to SND because Jiang Zemin did not support SIP, to the amazement of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's special representative, who was in charge of encouraging German businessmen to go to China together with Singapore. And that is what brought the matter to a head. We have been discussing it over these last 20 months and it has been finally settled.

    I should quote to the Member what one very senior Chinese official told us. He said that if he had been aware of SND, he would not have advised us to go to Suzhou. Therefore, this was a problem which we did not fully appreciate and their top leaders were not aware of either.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Clarification, Sir. Is the Deputy Prime Minister saying that even the adviser to the Singapore Government from China was not aware of the existence of the Suzhou New District at the point in time, and was the Singapore Government aware of the Suzhou New District at the point in time?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not say the adviser to the Singapore Government. I said a senior Chinese leader who gave us advice told us that he would have given us different advice had he been aware of SND. We were aware

Column: 1833

that SND existed. We did not know how big a problem it would pose and we believe the problem was manageable, and we were mistaken.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister that having learnt a lesson of the problems that we face in Suzhou with the Chinese officials, are we applying this lesson learnt in the other deals that we have in the other industrial parks? Are we facing any problems in the other parks that we have in China, for example, the Wuxi industrial park?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: I am not aware of the details of the Wuxi industrial Park. There is no G-to-G element in that. That is purely a commercial proposition. It is much less ambitious. They are not talking about 70 sq km with 8 sq km in phase I. They are going one sq km by one sq km, advancing as the project develops. From my not very up-to-date knowledge, I believe that they are also having some difficulties, not because of the Chinese partners but because investments into China generally are down this year and therefore they are finding it difficult to get tenants.
